fields.description:
h3. Summary

Unable to create Jira issue from Confluence page due to unintended cache.

This problem is reproducible when integrating Confluence with more than one Jira instances.

h3. Environment

* More than one Jira instances (I used Jira 7.10.1)

h3. Steps to Reproduce

# Prepare one Confluence instance and more than one Jira instances (e.g. Jira1 and Jira2)
# Make all the applications (Confluence, Jira1 and Jira2) use a same user base
#- e.g. I set up Jira 1 as Jira user server and configured Confluence and Jira2 to use it as user directory
# Create the following users in the user base
#- A user (named "User A") who has permissions to access (including create issue permission) all the applications
#- A user (named "User B") who has permissions to access only Confluence and Jira1 (no access of Jira2)
# Create application links using OAuth (with impersonation) as follows
#- Confluence <-> Jira1
#- Confluence <-> Jira2
# Logout from Confluence
# Login Confluence as "User B"
# Try to create an issue in Jira2 from a Confluence page
#- "User B" cannot create an issue as he/she doesn't have access of Jira2
# Logout Confluence
# Login Confluence as "User A"
# Try to create an issue in Jira2 from the Confluence page

h3. Expected Results

"User A" should be able to create the issue as he/she has access of Jira2.

h3. Actual Results

"User A" was not able to create the issue with an error "The version of selected Jira server is not supported. You may want to upgrade to the newer version or create issue in Jira." even though he/she has access of Jira2. (Of course, the Jira instance is supported version as well.)

 !screenshot-1.png|thumbnail! 
 
In case that "User A" tries to create the issue *before* "User B" do it, the issue creation continues to work without any problem for a while. (Technically, it seems to work until the cache is refreshed.)

h3. Notes

The above behavior is due to _Jira Resources Manager_ cache.

h3.Workaround

h4. Never use the caches
Configure Confluence not to use the caches.
# Go to _Confluence administrations > Cache Statistics > Jira Resources Manager_  and flush the cache
# Change the cache size to "1" with following the information in [Cache Performance Tuning|https://confluence.atlassian.com/doc/cache-performance-tuning-169119133.html]

(i) Please be careful to use this workaround. This workaround might cause some performance problem.

h4. Delete the wrong caches and create appropriate ones hourly
The caches are refreshed if they are not accessed for an hour. That's why, executing following commands hourly (by cron or something like that) could be the workaround.
{code}
curl -u <user>:<pass> 'http://<jira-base-url>/rest/cacheManagement/1.0/cacheEntries' -X DELETE --data 'cacheName=com.atlassian.confluence.plugins.createjiracontent.CachedJiraResourcesManager'
curl -u <user>:<pass> 'http://<jira-base-url>/rest/createjiracontent/1.0/get-jira-servers'
{code}
(i) Please replace {{<user>}}, {{<pass>}} with credentials of a Confluence admin user who has accesses of all the integrated Jira instances.
fields.summary: Unable to create Jira issue from Confluence page due to unintended cache

fields.description:
{panel:title=Atlassian Update – 09/03/2020|borderStyle=solid|borderColor=#ebf2f9 | titleBGColor=#ebf2f9 | bgColor=#ffffff}
Hello everyone,
 
We have recently reviewed this issue and as we're no longer able to replicate the issue in Confluence 7.1 and above and we will be marking this as Resolved.

If you are able to replicate the issue in Confluence 7.1 and later, do reach out to support using the link below to confirm, and to reopen this issue.
* [Contact Support|https://support.atlassian.com/contact]

Thank you
{panel}

*Symptom*
Favourites of Blogs and Personal Spaces cannot be removed in /users/viewmyfavourites.action page as attached.

*Steps to reproduce*
# Install Confluence Server 6.8.1
# Create a space and a page
# Add the space and page as a favourite
# Go to /users/viewmyfavourites.action page and click the stars to remove them from favourite

*Workaround*
* The favourites can be removed directly in the space by clicking on the *Saved for later* button. Note that if the page/space was deleted, it won't be possible to perform the workaround.
* Pages can also be removed when viewing *Saved for later* from [The dashboard|https://confluence.atlassian.com/doc/the-dashboard-139374.html]

*Diagnosis*
No exceptions are thrown on server side.
fields.summary: Cannot remove Favourites in Saved For Later section

fields.description:
h3. Summary
[Include Page Macro|https://confluence.atlassian.com/doc/include-page-macro-139514.html] will not render pages when there is a colon ":" in the page title.
Such page titles will be interpreted as {{spacekey:pagetitle}} as per [Confluence Wiki Markup|https://confluence.atlassian.com/doc/confluence-wiki-markup-251003035.html]
h3. Steps to Reproduce
 # Create a page and give it a title "test title:more to follow"
 # Create another page and add Include Page Macro to it
 # In Include Page Macro enter "test title:more to follow" page title

This also happens when restoring the old version of a page with 'Page include' macro and then editing the page breaks the Macro.

h3. Expected Results
Macro is working and page is rendered as it is within the same Space and we allow characters in page titles
h3. Actual Results

Page will not be rendered and error is shown on the page:
{code:borderStyle=solid}
Unable to render {include} The included page could not be found.
{code}

h3. Workaround
Adding Space key before page title will allow for the page to be rendered

h4. Note:
When the macro is edited itself - through the macro editor/browser - the macro works when you pick the page with the colon again. However, the issue seems to be recurring again.
fields.summary: Include Page Macro will not render pages with colon (:) in the title

fields.description:
Some of our users keep clicking the generic comment box at the bottom, when they actually try to reply to an existing comment - even if they are trying to respond to a nested existing comment.

While I can agree that we can blame those users, I still think it is not productive to make them feel bad... especially since this will not solve the issue for other new users who will have the same problem until corrected.

Therefore, I believe a different wording would probably help the users at least pause before clicking, for example something like "Start a new comment thread..." or whatever else you guys may deem more suitable.

Alternatively, this could maybe be changed into a button with wording that clearly informs the user that it will be a whole new comment thread, and not a correct way to reply to an existing comment?

fields.description:
When Confluence is starting up, it scans spring annotations for plugin classes. As part of this scanning process, it tries to ensure that these spring annotation classes are contained only in single jar. Responsible class for this action is AtlassianScannerBeanDefinitionParser. 
 If for some reason plugin can see spring annotations from another plugin that bundled them, plugin initialisation fails with error
{code:java}
$ find . -name "atlassian-confluence.log" | xargs grep -h "Cannot execute atlassian-spring-scanner-runtime" | sort -u
Caused by: java.lang.IllegalStateException: Cannot execute atlassian-spring-scanner-runtime: plugin has an extra copy of atlassian-spring-scanner-annotation classes, perhaps embedded inside the target plugin 'com.atlassian.confluence.plugins.confluence-baseurl-plugin'; embedding scanner-annotations is not supported since scanner version 2.0. Use 'mvn dependency:tree' and ensure the atlassian-spring-scanner-annotation dependency in your plugin has <scope>provided</scope>, not 'runtime' or 'compile', and you have NO dependency on atlassian-spring-scanner-runtime.
Caused by: java.lang.IllegalStateException: Cannot execute atlassian-spring-scanner-runtime: plugin has an extra copy of atlassian-spring-scanner-annotation classes, perhaps embedded inside the target plugin 'com.atlassian.confluence.plugins.confluence-scheduler-spi'; embedding scanner-annotations is not supported since scanner version 2.0. Use 'mvn dependency:tree' and ensure the atlassian-spring-scanner-annotation dependency in your plugin has <scope>provided</scope>, not 'runtime' or 'compile', and you have NO dependency on atlassian-spring-scanner-runtime.
Caused by: java.lang.IllegalStateException: Cannot execute atlassian-spring-scanner-runtime: plugin has an extra copy of atlassian-spring-scanner-annotation classes, perhaps embedded inside the target plugin 'com.atlassian.confluence.plugins.synchrony-interop'; embedding scanner-annotations is not supported since scanner version 2.0. Use 'mvn dependency:tree' and ensure the atlassian-spring-scanner-annotation dependency in your plugin has <scope>provided</scope>, not 'runtime' or 'compile', and you have NO dependency on atlassian-spring-scanner-runtime.
{code}
The problem here is that plugins from error message have nothing to do with bundling spring scanner. Because of OSGI non-deterministic wiring, these bundles see spring annotation from 'wrong' bundle.

What is causing these errors is the fact that some of the plugins use old 1.x version of atlassian-spring-scanner-annotation dependency. Here is the list of bundled plugins that do it:
 * atlassian-authentication-plugin
 * ImageEffectsPlugin
 * atlassian-webhooks-plugin
 * chart-plugin
 * confluence-collaborative-editor-plugin
 * troubleshooting:plugin-confluence
 * atlassian-playbook-blueprints
 * synchrony-interop

All of the plugins above (and maybe some more) should be upgraded to use 2.x version of spring scanner annotations. They should also use <provided> scope instead of <compile> or <runtime>. After new versions of these plugins are released, they should be used in Confluence.
fields.summary: Spring scanner library should be updated to v.2 in all plugins

fields.description:
h3. Summary

Invalid escape character of percent-encoding causes "URLDecoder: Incomplete trailing escape (%) pattern".

h3. Steps to Reproduce
# Create a page (P1) containing TOC macro and heading in multi-byte chars
** !Screenshot 2018-06-14 11.14.57.png|thumbnail! 
# Create a page (P2) containing a link to P1's heading
# Export the page P2 to PDF and confirm it works correctly
# Edit the page P2 to make the link's URL invalid against percent-encoding
**  !Screenshot 2018-06-14 11.13.02.png|thumbnail! 
** The example below contains invalid percent-encoding
{code:none}
http://confluence.localtest.me/display/SS/Linked+page#Linkedpage-%E6%97%A5%E6%9C%AC%E8%AA%9E%E3%81%AE%E8%A6%8B%E5%87%BA%E3%81%
{code}
# Export the page P2 to PDF and confirm it complains exception
** !Screenshot 2018-06-14 11.13.31.png|thumbnail!  

h3. Expected Results

PDF export doesn't get interrupted by broken link in page.

h3. Actual Results
The below exception is thrown in the logs/atlassian-confluence.log file:

{noformat}
java.lang.IllegalArgumentException: URLDecoder: Incomplete trailing escape (%) pattern
	at java.net.URLDecoder.decode(URLDecoder.java:187)
	at com.atlassian.confluence.extra.flyingpdf.html.LinkFixer.decodeTitle(LinkFixer.java:96)
{noformat}


h3.Workaround

Fix the broken link. If you are trying to export space to PDF, it's hard to identify which page causing the exception. Refer [How to identify which page facing unrecoverable error|https://community.atlassian.com/t5/Confluence-articles/How-to-identify-which-page-facing-unrecoverable-error-and/ba-p/817641] for those cases.
fields.summary: Broken percent-encoding in link interrupts PDF export
